awd_titl_txt: An informal learning model of genetic and genomic education for adult, bilingual learners
awd_abstract_narration:
The overall goal of this project is to develop and evaluate a community model of informal genomic education that is culturally and educationally appropriate for low-literacy Latino adults born in Mexico and Central America (MCA). The community engagement strategy and materials created will be designed to lead to three learning outcomes: increased interest and engagement with genomics, change in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) attitudes and self-identity, and increased understanding about gene function and the human genome.  The model created in this project will have the potential to inform other educational efforts, nationally.

Semi-structured in-depth interviews will be conducted in Spanish with 60 MCA Latinos to delineate beliefs and knowledge about genetic and genomic concepts and transmission of traits. Interview transcripts will be systematically analyzed to identify explanations about trait transmission, and familiarity with genetic and genomic concepts. Variation in responses across geographic and cultural regions will be noted. Knowledge from this analysis will be used to develop a meaningful community-based learning program about genomics. Lay community educators will facilitate informal learning with MCA adults about genetics and genomics, including gene-environment interactions. This project will use information about environmental exposures (e.g., residential pesticides) as a vehicle to pique participants' interest and illustrate genetic and genomic content. It will compare outcomes for 100 participants who receive practical strategies only to reduce negative and increase positive environmental exposures, respectively, to 100 participants who also receive genetic and genomic content.  The strategy and materials will be disseminated through journal articles and presentations at meetings that focus on informal STEM education. The process and content will be rigorously evaluated throughout the project.

This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.

por.por_cntn:
Our project was designed to engage adults who are not native English speakers, many of whom may have limited formal education, in learning experiences about genomics. After systematically analyzing the transcripts of 60 semi-structured, in-depth interviews with adults who were born in Mexico or Central American (MCA) to identify the range of ways they think and talk about heredity and what they know about genes and DNA, we created five learning modules, each of which was built on the content of prior modules. We used the "hook" of providing learners with information about how to keep their families healthy to encourage adults born in MCA, more than 1/3 of whom had less than a seventh-grade education by design, to engage in the learning experiences about genomics, a topic that could be intimidating for many. We embedded the genomic content in the linguistically and culturally appropriate materials. To enable those with the very limited education to understand the topic, we created materials that did not assume any science knowledge, not even what a cell is at the most general level. The materials included short engaging videos in which the genomic content was embedded within the broader narrative about preparing for a child's first birthday. Flipcharts and hands-on activities reinforced the content and facilitated engagement between learners and facilitators. Lay educators who were respected members of the community facilitated the informal learning; they worked with learners at locations convenient to the learners, such as their homes. The lay educators did not have expertise in science. They were trained by the team, and we designed learning materials that they could use effectively.  We evaluated the effectiveness of the learning opportunities on changes in genomic knowledge and attitudes toward science. Engaging in the learning opportunities with genomic content significantly increased genomic knowledge. The effect of the exposure to genomics on science attitudes was less distinct, possibly due in part to participants′ appropriate perception that the information about the potential impact of environmental exposures on their families′ health was science, although less complex than content about genomics.

This project has intellectual merit. It added to our knowledge by demonstrating that the strategy used to develop materials for adults born outside the U.S. and who may have limited formal science education resulted was effective at increaing their genomic knowledge. It demonstrated that adults with limited formal education, including those who have limited English literacy, can learn about genomics when provided with appropriate materials and supports. Furthermore, it suggests that use of lay educators may be an effective way to engage hard to reach populations in informal STEM learning opportunities.

The broader impacts are closely tied to the intellectual merit. Through the implementation component of the project itself, many Latinx adults, including those with very limited formal education, increased their science literacy. The project also addressed a strategy that could be used to develop materials for adults often underserved within the informal STEM learning ecosystem. Furthermore, it suggests that lay educators from those communities may effectively engage adults in these opportunities. Finally, materials developed during the project are available for use. The Spanish language materials created to teach adults about genomics are freely available at https://school.wakehealth.edu/departments/family-and-community-medicine/nuestra-familia-sana/espanol. English translations of those materials are available at  https://school.wakehealth.edu/departments/family-and-community-medicine/nuestra-familia-sana. The following materials are available for each of the five modules: videos, flipcharts, lesson plans, and an educator lesson manual. A Train the Trainer Manual is also found on each website.
